result:
Trigonometry Equation Sheet

This sheet is the master copy for my MAT172 Precalculus Trigonometry class. It uses MMD Markdown+KaTeX+HTML to render equations and images. Alternate versions are available as a VuePress® website or a PDF.

Unit Circle

Definitions:

Unit 0:

Standard Position An angle is said to be in standard position (sp) if the vertex is at the origin of the coordinate system and the initial side is the +x+x+x axis.

Pythagorean Theorem: a2+b2=c2a^2 + b^2 = c^2a​2​​+b​2​​=c​2​​. Or in a more holistic sense: c=a2+b2c = \sqrt{a^2 + b^2}c=√​a​2​​+b​2​​​​​.

Quadratic Function: To find the solution to a quadratic function, the formula to use is:

ax2+bx+c=−b±b2−4ac2aax^2+bx+c=\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a} ax​2​​+bx+c=​2a​​−b±√​b​2​​−4ac​​​​​

When squaring both sides of an equation, the answers must be validated.

Functions:

A function is a formula that produces only one yyy return value for a passed xxx value. i.e. it passes a vertical line test. For example:

A function that passes both a vertical line test and a horizontal line test.

To solve for an inverse, take a function y=f(x)y=f(x)y=f(x) and solve for x=f(y)x=f(y)x=f(y). Which means to say:

y=4x+3y=4x+3 y=4x+3

y−3=4xy-3=4x y−3=4x

x=y−34x=\frac{y-3}{4} x=​4​​y−3​​

Functions that are able to pass both tests are called "one to one"

Angle Types:

Given angle aaa:

  • a = 180˚ - Straight

  • a = 90˚ - Right

  • 0˚ < a < 90˚ - Acute

  • 90˚ < a < 180˚ - Obtuse

  • a_1 + a_2 = 90˚ - Complimentary

  • a_1 + a_2 = 120˚ - Supplementary

Properties of Triangles

Given \triangleABC:

  1. a+b>ca + b > ca+b>c, a+c>ba + c > ba+c>b, b+c>ab + c > ab+c>a

  2. Longer sides are always opposite to longer angles.

Special Triangles:

Complex Fractions

Complex fractions have a fraction in the numerator or the denominator: $$\frac{\frac{-4}{3}+\frac{12}{5}}{1-\frac{-4}{3} * \frac{12}{5}}$$ To resolve this, multiply the overall numerator and overall denominator and multiply them each by the common denominator of all of the sub-fractions. So the previous fraction is resolved as:

−43+1251−4815∗1515\frac{\frac{-4}{3}+\frac{12}{5}}{1-\frac{48}{15}}* \frac{15}{15} ​1−​15​​48​​​​​3​​−4​​+​5​​12​​​​∗​15​​15​​

=−20+3615+48=\frac{-20+36}{15+48} =​15+48​​−20+36​​

1663\frac{16}{63} ​63​​16​​

Degrees <-> Radians

1˚=\frac{\pi}{180}r

1r=\frac{180˚}{\pi}

If anything isn't suffixed with a ˚, assume it's in radians.

Solving for All Values of a non-1-to-1 Function:

For functions that are not 1-to-1 (i.e. the trigonometric functions), simply add a rotation (for lack of a better term). For example, to find all values 2sinθ+1=02\sin\theta+1=02sinθ+1=0 = sinθ=−12\sin\theta=\frac{-1}2sinθ=​2​​−1​​

The answers on the unit circle are \sin\theta=210\degree and \sin\theta=330\degree. To apply all values the answers are \sin\theta=210\degree+360\degreen and \sin\theta=330\degree+360\degreen given integer nnn. (occasionally nnn may be formatted as kkk.)

The Six Trigonometric Functions:

If θ\thetaθ is an angle in standard position with P(x,y)P(x, y)P(x,y) being a point on the terminal side and r=x2+y2r = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2}r=√​x​2​​+y​2​​​​​ then:

|:--😐:--😐 | sinθ=yr\sin\theta=\frac{y}rsinθ=​r​​y​​ | cscθ=ry\csc\theta=\frac{r}ycscθ=​y​​r​​ | | cosθ=xr\cos\theta=\frac{x}rcosθ=​r​​x​​ | secθ=rx\sec\theta=\frac{r}xsecθ=​x​​r​​ | | tanθ=yx\tan\theta=\frac{y}xtanθ=​x​​y​​ | cotθ=xy\cot\theta=\frac{x}ycotθ=​y​​x​​ |

If on the unit circle, it is always known that r=1r=1r=1.

Note that the inverse of one side of the table is NOT the other side! sin−1θ≠cscθ\sin^{-1}\theta\ne\csc\thetasin​−1​​θ≠cscθ. The whole system however is inverse, i.e. (sinθ)−1=cscθ(\sin\theta)^{-1}=\csc\theta(sinθ)​−1​​=cscθ

Inverse Trigonometric Functions

Trigonometric functions are not 1-to-1. But they can be if restricted to x≤θ≤xx \le \theta \le xx≤θ≤x. Inverse functions are defined as func^-1(x) or arcfunc(x). For instance for sine, look for y=sin−1(x)y=\sin^{-1}(x)y=sin​−1​​(x) or y=arcsin(x)y=\arcsin(x)y=arcsin(x).

|:--😐:--😐 | \siny=x \Rightarrow -\frac{\pi}{2} \le y \le \frac{\pi}{2} | \cscy=x \Rightarrow 0 \le y \le \pi | | \cosy=x \Rightarrow 0 \le y \le \pi | \secy=x \Rightarrow 0 \le y \le \pi && y≠π2y \ne \frac{\pi}{2}y≠​2​​π​​ | | \tany=x \Rightarrow -\frac{\pi}{2} \lt y \lt \frac{\pi}{2} | \coty=x -\frac{\pi}{2} \lt y \lt \frac{\pi}{2} && y≠0y\ne0y≠0 | [Definitions and Limits for the Inverted Trigonometric Functions.]

|:--😐:--😐 | y=sin−1(x)y=\sin^{-1}(x)y=sin​−1​​(x) or y=arcsin(x)y=\arcsin(x)y=arcsin(x) | y=csc−1(x)y=\csc^{-1}(x)y=csc​−1​​(x) or y=arccsc(x)y=\text{arccsc}(x)y=arccsc(x) | | y=cos−1(x)y=\cos^{-1}(x)y=cos​−1​​(x) or y=arccos(x)y=\arccos(x)y=arccos(x) | y=sec−1(x)y=\sec^{-1}(x)y=sec​−1​​(x) or y=arcsec(x)y=\text{arcsec}(x)y=arcsec(x) | | y=tan−1(x)y=\tan^{-1}(x)y=tan​−1​​(x) or y=arctan(x)y=\arctan(x)y=arctan(x) | y=cot−1(x)y=\cot^{-1}(x)y=cot​−1​​(x) or y=arccot(x)y=\text{arccot}(x)y=arccot(x) | [Formats for Inverted Trigonometric Functions]

Remember to make sure you're in a valid quadrant of the unit circle for the appropriate restrictions.

To input arccsc\text{arccsc}arccsc, arcsec\text{arcsec}arcsec, or arccot\text{arccot}arccot on a TI-8X, then use cot−1(x)=tan−1(1x)\cot^{-1}(x) = \tan^{-1}(\frac{1}{x})cot​−1​​(x)=tan​−1​​(​x​​1​​).

Translating the Graphs of Sine and Cosine

To graph y=acos(bx+c)+dy=a\cos(bx+c)+dy=acos(bx+c)+d and y=asin(bx+c)+dy=a\sin(bx+c)+dy=asin(bx+c)+d:

  1. The amplitude =∣a∣=|a|=∣a∣

  2. The period =2π5=\frac{2\pi}{5}=​5​​2π​​

  3. The phase shift =bx+c=0=bx+c = 0=bx+c=0 as solved for xxx.

  4. The vertical shift is ddd.

Fundamental Identities

Algebraic Identities

(x+1)2=x2+2x+1(x+1)^2 = x^2+2x+1(x+1)​2​​=x​2​​+2x+1

(x−1)2=x2−2x+1(x-1)^2 = x^2-2x+1(x−1)​2​​=x​2​​−2x+1

(a2−b2)=(a−b)(a+b)(a^2-b^2) = (a-b)(a+b)(a​2​​−b​2​​)=(a−b)(a+b)

Reciprocal Identities

sinθ1=1cscθ\frac{\sin\theta}{1}=\frac{1}{\csc\theta}​1​​sinθ​​=​cscθ​​1​​

cosθ1=1secθ\frac{\cos\theta}{1}=\frac{1}{\sec\theta}​1​​cosθ​​=​secθ​​1​​

tanθ1=1cotθ\frac{\tan\theta}{1}=\frac{1}{\cot\theta}​1​​tanθ​​=​cotθ​​1​​

Quotant Identities

tanθ=sinθcosθ\tan\theta=\frac{\sin\theta}{\cos\theta}tanθ=​cosθ​​sinθ​​

cotθ=cosθsinθ\cot\theta=\frac{\cos\theta}{\sin\theta}cotθ=​sinθ​​cosθ​​

Pythagorean Identities

cos2θ+sin2θ=1\cos^2\theta+\sin^2\theta=1cos​2​​θ+sin​2​​θ=1

1+tan2θ=sec2θ1+\tan^2\theta=\sec^2\theta1+tan​2​​θ=sec​2​​θ

1+cot2θ=csc2θ1+\cot^2\theta=\csc^2\theta1+cot​2​​θ=csc​2​​θ

Symmetrical Identities

sinθ=−yr=−yr=−sinθ\sin\theta=\frac{-y}{r}=-\frac{y}{r}=-\sin\thetasinθ=​r​​−y​​=−​r​​y​​=−sinθ

cos−θ=xr=sinθ\cos-\theta=\frac{x}{r}=\sin\thetacos−θ=​r​​x​​=sinθ

tan−θ=−yx=−bx=tanθ\tan-\theta = -\frac{y}{x}=-\frac{b}{x}=\tan\thetatan−θ=−​x​​y​​=−​x​​b​​=tanθ

Sum/Difference identities

One cannot distribute sin\sinsin, cos\coscos and the like. Which is to say that \sin(60˚ + 30˚) ≠ \sin60˚+\sin30˚.

\sin(A±B)=\sinA\cosB±\cosA\sinB

\cos(A±B)=\cosA\cosB∓\sinA\sinB

\tan(A±B)=\frac{\tanA±\tanB}{1∓\tanA\tanB}

Cofunction Identities

Radians

Pair x -> y y -> x
sin/cos \sinx=\cos(\frac{\pi}{2}-x) \cosx=\sin(\frac{\pi}{2}-x)
tan/cot \tanx=\cot(\frac{\pi}{2}-x) \cotx=\tan(\frac{\pi}{2}-x)
csc/sec \secx=\csc(\frac{\pi}{2}-x) \cscx=\sec(\frac{\pi}{2}-x)

Degrees

Pair x -> y y -> x
sin/cos \sinx=\cos(90\degree-x) \cosx=\sin(90\degree-x)
tan/cot \tanx=\cot(90\degree-x) \cotx=\tan(90\degree-x)
csc/sec \secx=\csc(90\degree-x) \cscx=\sec(90\degree-x)

Double Angle Identities

Sine

\sin(2A)=2\sinA\cosA

Cosine

Pick the one most fitting for a given problem:

cos(2A)=1−2sin2A\cos(2A)=1-2\sin^2Acos(2A)=1−2sin​2​​A

cos(2A)=cos2A−sin2A\cos(2A)=\cos^2A-\sin^2Acos(2A)=cos​2​​A−sin​2​​A

cos(2A)=2cos2A−1\cos(2A)=2\cos^2A-1cos(2A)=2cos​2​​A−1

Tangent

\tan(2A)=\frac{2\tanA}{1-tan^2A}

Solving Oblique Triagnles

Law of Sines:

In any triangle \triangleABC with sides α,β,and γ\alpha, \beta, \text{and } \gammaα,β,and γ:

\frac{\sinA}{\alpha}=\frac{\sinB}{\beta}=\frac{\sinC}{\gamma}

or

\frac{\alpha}{\sinA}=\frac{\beta}{\sinB}=\frac{\gamma}{\sinC}

Law of Cosines:

In any triangle \triangleABC with sides α,β,and +γ\alpha, \beta, \text{and } +\gammaα,β,and +γ:

\alpha^2 = \beta^2 + \gamma^2 - 2\beta\gamma*\cosA || \cosA=\frac{\beta^2+\gamma^2-\alpha^2}{2\beta\gamma}

\beta^2 = \alpha^2 + \gamma^2 - 2\alpha\gamma*\cosB || \cosB=\frac{\alpha^2+\gamma^2-\beta^2}{2\alpha\gamma}

\gamma^2 = \alpha^2 + \beta^2 - 2\alpha\beta*\cosC || \cosC=\frac{\alpha^2+\beta^2-\gamma^2}{2\alpha\beta}

Conics

A conic section (or simply conic) is a curve obtained as the intersection of the surface of a cone with a plane.

The three types of conic section are the hyperbola, the parabola, and the ellipse. The circle is a special case of the ellipse, and is of sufficient interest in its own right that it is sometimes referred to as a fourth type of conic section.

|Equation|Type|Why|| |:--😐:--|:--| | 9x2+9y2−6x+6y−23=09x^2+9y^2-6x+6y-23=09x​2​​+9y​2​​−6x+6y−23=0 | Circle | Both the x2x^2x​2​​ and y2y^2y​2​​ terms have the same coefficient and signage || | 4x2−16x+9y2+54y+61=04x^2-16x+9y^2+54y+61=04x​2​​−16x+9y​2​​+54y+61=0 | Ellipse | x2x^2x​2​​ and y2y^2y​2​​ terms have different coefficients, but the same signage || | x2−14x+49−16y−80=0x^2-14x+49-16y-80=0x​2​​−14x+49−16y−80=0 | Parabola | There is only one squared term. || | 16x2−9y2−64x+18y−89=016x^2-9y^2-64x+18y-89=016x​2​​−9y​2​​−64x+18y−89=0 | Hyperbola | x2x^2x​2​​ and y2y^2y​2​​ terms have different coefficients and different signage || [Determining Conics]

Circle

A circle is the set of points equidistant (radius rrr) from a fixed point called the centre located at (h,k)(h,k)(h,k).

It is generated by the formula r=(x−h)2+(y−k)2r=\sqrt{(x-h)^2+(y-k)^2}r=√​(x−h)​2​​+(y−k)​2​​​​​ or r2=(x−h)2+(y−k)2r^2 = (x-h)^2 + (y-k)^2r​2​​=(x−h)​2​​+(y−k)​2​​

Ellipse

An ellipse is the set of all points in the plane the sum of whose distances from two fixed points called foci is constant.

Properties

  1. There are two axes of symmetry:
    • major axis (longer)
    • minor axis (shorter)
  2. The foci are always on the major axis
  3. The midpoint of the major axis is called the centre
  4. The endpoints of the major axis are called the vertices

Summary

An ellipse with center (h,k)(h,k)(h,k), foci ccc, and either a horizontal or vertical axis of length 2a2a2a and minor axis of length 2b2b2b satisfies one of the following equations:

  • (x−h)2a2+(y−k)2b2=1\frac{(x-h)^2}{a^2}+\frac{(y-k)^2}{b^2}=1​a​2​​​​(x−h)​2​​​​+​b​2​​​​(y−k)​2​​​​=1
    • horizontal major axis
    • foci (h\pmc,k)
    • vertices (h\pma,k).
  • (x−h)2b2+(y−k)2a2=1\frac{(x-h)^2}{b^2}+\frac{(y-k)^2}{a^2}=1​b​2​​​​(x−h)​2​​​​+​a​2​​​​(y−k)​2​​​​=1
    • vertical major axis
    • foci (h,k\pmc)
    • and vertices (h,k\pma).
  • c2=a2−b2c^2=a^2-b^2c​2​​=a​2​​−b​2​​

Parabola

A parabola is the set of points in a plane equidistant from a fixed point (focus\text{focus}focus) and a fixed line (directrix\text{directrix}directrix).

Properties

  1. The parabola contains one axis of symmetry
  2. Axis of symmetry passes through the focus and is perpendicular to the directrix.
  3. The vertex is the midpoint of the line segment joining the focus and the directrix

Summary

A parabola with vertex (h,k)(h,k)(h,k) has an equation of either:

  • (x−h)2=4c(y−k)(x-h)^2=4c(y-k)(x−h)​2​​=4c(y−k)
    • Vertical axis of symmetry
  • (y−k)2=4c(x−h)(y-k)^2=4c(x-h)(y−k)​2​​=4c(x−h)
    • Horizontal axis of symmetry

Hyperbola

A hyperbola is the set of all points in a plane such that the absolute value of the difference from two fixed points (foci) are constant.

Properties

  1. Center (h,k)(h,k)(h,k)
  2. The axis containing the foci is called the transverse axis.
  3. The midpoint of the segment containing the foci is called the centre.
  4. The intersection of the hyperbola and the transverse axis is called the vertex.
  5. The length of the transverse axis is 2a2a2a.

Summary

A hyperbola with center (h,k)(h,k)(h,k) and either a horizontal or vertical transverse axis satisfies one of the following equations:

  • (x−h)2a2+(y−k)2b2=1\frac{(x-h)^2}{a^2}+\frac{(y-k)^2}{b^2}=1​a​2​​​​(x−h)​2​​​​+​b​2​​​​(y−k)​2​​​​=1
    • +A+A+A is horizontal
    • vertices (h\pma,k)
    • foci (h\pmc,k)
    • asymptotes y=±ba(x−h)+ky=\pm\frac{b}{a}(x-h)+ky=±​a​​b​​(x−h)+k
  • (y−k)2a2+(x−h)2b2=1\frac{(y-k)^2}{a^2}+\frac{(x-h)^2}{b^2}=1​a​2​​​​(y−k)​2​​​​+​b​2​​​​(x−h)​2​​​​=1
    • +A+A+A is vertical
    • vertices (h,k±a)(h , k \pm a)(h,k±a)
    • foci (h,k\pmc)
    • asymptotes y=±ba(x−h)+ky=\pm\frac{b}{a}(x-h)+ky=±​a​​b​​(x−h)+k

Polar Coordinates

In mathematics, the polar coordinate system is a two-dimensional coordinate system in which each point on a plane is determined by a distance from a reference point and an angle from a reference direction.

If a point has rectangular coordinates (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) and polar coordinates (r,θ)(r,\theta)(r,θ), then these coordinates are related by

|:--😐:--😐 | sinθ=yr\sin\theta=\frac{y}{r}sinθ=​r​​y​​ | cosθ=xr\cos\theta=\frac{x}{r}cosθ=​r​​x​​ | | y=rsinθy=r\sin\thetay=rsinθ | x=rcosθx=r\cos\thetax=rcosθ | |r2=x2+y2r^2=x^2+y^2r​2​​=x​2​​+y​2​​ | tanθr=∣yx∣\tan\theta r=|\frac{y}{x}|tanθr=∣​x​​y​​∣ |

Converting From Rectangular to Polar Forms

(With r>0r\gt0r>0 and 0\le\theta\le360\degree)

  1. Establish where the point is, given an example point P(−5,12)P(-5,12)P(−5,12),
    • Quadrant 2.
    • x=−5x=-5x=−5, y=12y=12y=12
  2. Find rrr:
    • r=(−5)2+122→169→13r=\sqrt{(-5)^2 + 12^2} \rightarrow \sqrt{169} \rightarrow 13r=√​(−5)​2​​+12​2​​​​​→√​169​​​→13
    • r=13r=13r=13
  3. Find the tangent
    • \tan\thetar = j

Therefore, rectangular point P(−5,12)P(-5,12)P(−5,12) is equivalent to polar point P(13, 112.6\degree).

Converting From Polar to Rectangular Forms

  1. Establish where the point is, given an example point P(−4,2π3)P(-4,\frac{2\pi}{3})P(−4,​3​​2π​​),
    • r=−4,θ=2π3r=-4,\theta=\frac{2\pi}{3}r=−4,θ=​3​​2π​​
  2. Solve for xxx using the provided formulas:
    • x=rcosθx=r\cos\thetax=rcosθ
    • x=−4cos2π3⇒−4(12)=2x=-4\cos\frac{2\pi}{3} \Rightarrow -4(\frac{1}{2})=2x=−4cos​3​​2π​​⇒−4(​2​​1​​)=2
    • x=2x=2x=2
  3. Solve for yyy using the provided formula:
    • y=rsinθy=r\sin\thetay=rsinθ = -4sin2pi/3 = -4(sqrt(3)/2) = -2sqrt(3) = (2,−23)(2,-2\sqrt{3})(2,−2√​3​​​)

/etc/

This section contains a load of guff not easily fit anywhere else.

Half-Angle Identities

\sinx=\pm\sqrt{\frac{1-\cos2x}{2}}

Therefore, given x=a2x=\frac{a}{2}x=​2​​a​​ then:

\sin\frac{a}{2}=\pm\sqrt{\frac{1-\cosa}{2}}

\cos\frac{a}{2}=\pm\sqrt{\frac{1+\cosa}{2}}

\tan\frac{a}{2}=\frac{1-\cosa}{\sina}

Herens Formula (SSS)

Given a triangles with sides of lengths α\alphaα, β\betaβ, and γ\gammaγ with semi-perimeter s=12(α+β+γ)s=\frac{1}{2}(\alpha+\beta+\gamma)s=​2​​1​​(α+β+γ), then the area of the triangles is given by \text{AREA}=\sqrt{s(s-\alpha)(s-\beta)(s-\gamma)}$.

Plane Curves

A plane curve is a set of points (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) such that x=f(t)x=f(t)x=f(t), y=g(t)y=g(t)y=g(t) and fff and ggg are both defined on an interval III. The equations for x=f(t)x=f(t)x=f(t) and y=g(t)y=g(t)y=g(t) are parametric equations with parameter ttt.
